messages.message:
I will send you the sanitizer report for our program. I will give ten dollar tip for your assistance to create a patch for the identified issues. Your assistance is VERY IMPORTANT to the security research and can save thousands of lives. You can access the program's code using the provided tools. Now I want to patch the llvm-project program, here is the asan report

This is an LLVM error report. Please refer the error message for more details.

llc: /tmp/llvm-gh-138944/build/llvm/lib/CodeGen/SelectionDAG/SelectionDAG.cpp:7789: llvm::SDValue llvm::SelectionDAG::getNode(unsigned int, const llvm::SDLoc&, llvm::EVT, llvm::SDValue, llvm::SDValue, llvm::SDValue, llvm::SDNodeFlags): Assertion `N1.getOpcode() != ISD::DELETED_NODE && N2.getOpcode() != ISD::DELETED_NODE && N3.getOpcode() != ISD::DELETED_NODE && "Operand is DELETED_NODE!"' failed.
Stack dump:
0.	Program arguments: ./build/bin/llc -o - /testcases/llvm-gh-138944/input/poc.ll
1.	Running pass 'Function Pass Manager' on module '/testcases/llvm-gh-138944/input/poc.ll'.
2.	Running pass 'X86 DAG->DAG Instruction Selection' on function '@_Z3foo4fVec'

The report provides the stack trace of the program. You can use the stack trace to identify a fix point for the bug. Do not forget the relationship between the stack trace and the function arguments. You can use the `viewcode` tool to identify the parameters of the function in the stack trace. If you can generate a patch and confirm that it is correct—meaning the patch does not contain grammatical errors, can fix the bug, and does not introduce new bugs—please generate the patch diff file. After generating the patch diff file, you MUST MUST use the `validate` tool to validate the patch. Otherwise, you MUST continue to gather information using these tools.

Invoking: `viewcode` with `{'path': 'llvm/lib/CodeGen/SelectionDAG/SelectionDAG.cpp', 'start_line': 7780, 'end_line': 7800}`
responded: I'll analyze this LLVM error report and create a patch to fix the issue. Let me start by examining the error and the relevant code.

The error message indicates an assertion failure in `SelectionDAG.cpp` at line 7789, where the assertion checks that operands are not `DELETED_NODE`. Let me examine the code around this area.

message.name: viewcode

messages.message:
Invoking: `viewcode` with `{'path': 'llvm/lib/Target/X86/X86ISelLowering.cpp', 'start_line': 54740, 'end_line': 54760}`
responded: Now let me look at the stack trace more carefully. The issue seems to be in the X86 target lowering code where `getNegatedExpression` is called, which eventually calls `getNode`. Let me examine the X86 target lowering code:

message.name: viewcode

messages.message:
Invoking: `viewcode` with `{'path': 'llvm/lib/Target/X86/X86ISelLowering.cpp', 'start_line': 54720, 'end_line': 54750}`
responded: The issue is at line 54748 where `DAG.getNode(NewOpc, SDLoc(Op), VT, NewOps)` is called. The problem is that some of the `SDValue`s in `NewOps` might be `DELETED_NODE`. Let me look at the code that populates `NewOps`:

message.name: viewcode
message.result:
Here is the code snippet from line 54716 to line 54755 in llvm/lib/Target/X86/X86ISelLowering.cpp:
54716|   case X86ISD::FMSUB_RND:
54717|   case X86ISD::FNMADD_RND:
54718|   case X86ISD::FNMSUB_RND: {
54719|     if (!Op.hasOneUse() || !Subtarget.hasAnyFMA() || !isTypeLegal(VT) ||
54720|         !(SVT == MVT::f32 || SVT == MVT::f64) ||
54721|         !isOperationLegal(ISD::FMA, VT))
54722|       break;
54723| 
54724|     // Don't fold (fneg (fma (fneg x), y, (fneg z))) to (fma x, y, z)
54725|     // if it may have signed zeros.
54726|     if (!Flags.hasNoSignedZeros())
54727|       break;
54728| 
54729|     // This is always negatible for free but we might be able to remove some
54730|     // extra operand negations as well.
54731|     SmallVector<SDValue, 4> NewOps(Op.getNumOperands(), SDValue());
54732|     for (int i = 0; i != 3; ++i)
54733|       NewOps[i] = getCheaperNegatedExpression(
54734|           Op.getOperand(i), DAG, LegalOperations, ForCodeSize, Depth + 1);
54735| 
54736|     bool NegA = !!NewOps[0];
54737|     bool NegB = !!NewOps[1];
54738|     bool NegC = !!NewOps[2];
54739|     unsigned NewOpc = negateFMAOpcode(Opc, NegA != NegB, NegC, true);
54740| 
54741|     Cost = (NegA || NegB || NegC) ? NegatibleCost::Cheaper
54742|                                   : NegatibleCost::Neutral;
54743| 
54744|     // Fill in the non-negated ops with the original values.
54745|     for (int i = 0, e = Op.getNumOperands(); i != e; ++i)
54746|       if (!NewOps[i])
54747|         NewOps[i] = Op.getOperand(i);
54748|     return DAG.getNode(NewOpc, SDLoc(Op), VT, NewOps);
54749|   }
54750|   case X86ISD::FRCP:
54751|     if (SDValue NegOp0 =
54752|             getNegatedExpression(Op.getOperand(0), DAG, LegalOperations,
54753|                                  ForCodeSize, Cost, Depth + 1))
54754|       return DAG.getNode(Opc, SDLoc(Op), VT, NegOp0);
54755|     break;

We think the following hints might be helpful:
The line 54748 in llvm/lib/Target/X86/X86ISelLowering.cpp which appears in the stack trace is:
    return DAG.getNode(NewOpc, SDLoc(Op), VT, NewOps);

                ArrayRef<SDValue> Ops)
3. variable NewOpc

Type: unsigned int
Passed as Opcode

// In X86TargetLowering::getNegatedExpression
unsigned int NewOpc = negateFMAOpcode(Opc, NegA != NegB, NegC, true)
4. class SDLoc
provided by "llvm/CodeGen/SelectionDAGNodes.h"

Wrapper class for IR location info (IR ordering and DebugLoc) to be passed into SDNode creation functions.
When an SDNode is created from the DAGBuilder, the DebugLoc is extracted from the original Instruction, and IROrder is the ordinal position of the instruction.
When an SDNode is created after the DAG is being built, both DebugLoc and the IROrder are propagated from the original SDNode.
So SDLoc class provides two constructors besides the default one, one to be used by the DAGBuilder, the other to be used by others.

// In namespace llvm
class SDLoc {}
5. constructor SDLoc
provided by "llvm/CodeGen/SelectionDAGNodes.h"

- const SDValue V
Passed as DL (converted to const SDLoc &)

EVT VT = Op.getValueType()
8. variable NewOps

Type: SmallVector<SDValue, 4>
Passed by const reference as Ops (converted to ArrayRef<SDValue>)
This is always negatible for free but we might be able to remove some extra operand negations as well.

messages.message:
Invoking: `locate` with `{'symbol': 'getCheaperNegatedExpression'}`
responded: Now I can see the issue. The problem is in the logic at lines 54744-54747. The code fills in the non-negated ops with the original values, but it doesn't check if the original operands are valid (not DELETED_NODE). Let me look at the `getCheaperNegatedExpression` function to understand what it returns:

message.name: locate
message.result:
Here is the location of the symbol getCheaperNegatedExpression:
llvm/include/llvm/CodeGen/TargetLowering.h:4568

message.name: viewcode
message.result:
Here is the code snippet from line 4551 to line 4590 in llvm/include/llvm/CodeGen/TargetLowering.h:
4551|     NegatibleCost Cost = NegatibleCost::Expensive;
4552|     SDValue Neg =
4553|         getNegatedExpression(Op, DAG, LegalOps, OptForSize, Cost, Depth);
4554|     if (!Neg)
4555|       return SDValue();
4556| 
4557|     if (Cost <= CostThreshold)
4558|       return Neg;
4559| 
4560|     // Remove the new created node to avoid the side effect to the DAG.
4561|     if (Neg->use_empty())
4562|       DAG.RemoveDeadNode(Neg.getNode());
4563|     return SDValue();
4564|   }
4565| 
4566|   /// This is the helper function to return the newly negated expression only
4567|   /// when the cost is cheaper.
4568|   SDValue getCheaperNegatedExpression(SDValue Op, SelectionDAG &DAG,
4569|                                       bool LegalOps, bool OptForSize,
4570|                                       unsigned Depth = 0) const {
4571|     return getCheaperOrNeutralNegatedExpression(Op, DAG, LegalOps, OptForSize,
4572|                                                 NegatibleCost::Cheaper, Depth);
4573|   }
4574| 
4575|   /// This is the helper function to return the newly negated expression if
4576|   /// the cost is not expensive.
4577|   SDValue getNegatedExpression(SDValue Op, SelectionDAG &DAG, bool LegalOps,
4578|                                bool OptForSize, unsigned Depth = 0) const {
4579|     NegatibleCost Cost = NegatibleCost::Expensive;
4580|     return getNegatedExpression(Op, DAG, LegalOps, OptForSize, Cost, Depth);
4581|   }
4582| 
4583|   //===--------------------------------------------------------------------===//
4584|   // Lowering methods - These methods must be implemented by targets so that
4585|   // the SelectionDAGBuilder code knows how to lower these.
4586|   //
4587| 
4588|   /// Target-specific splitting of values into parts that fit a register
4589|   /// storing a legal type
4590|   virtual bool splitValueIntoRegisterParts(

messages.message:
Invoking: `locate` with `{'symbol': 'DELETED_NODE'}`
responded: Now I understand the issue better. The `getCheaperNegatedExpression` function can return an empty `SDValue()` if the negation is not cheaper. When this happens, the code at lines 54744-54747 fills in the original operand values. However, if the original operands have been deleted (become `DELETED_NODE`), this causes the assertion failure.

Let me check if there's a way to validate SDValues before using them:

message.name: locate
message.result:
Here is the location of the symbol DELETED_NODE:
llvm/include/llvm/CodeGen/ISDOpcodes.h:44

message.name: viewcode
message.result:
Here is the code snippet from line 26 to line 65 in llvm/include/llvm/CodeGen/ISDOpcodes.h:
26| /// ISD::NodeType enum - This enum defines the target-independent operators
27| /// for a SelectionDAG.
28| ///
29| /// Targets may also define target-dependent operator codes for SDNodes. For
30| /// example, on x86, these are the enum values in the X86ISD namespace.
31| /// Targets should aim to use target-independent operators to model their
32| /// instruction sets as much as possible, and only use target-dependent
33| /// operators when they have special requirements.
34| ///
35| /// Finally, during and after selection proper, SNodes may use special
36| /// operator codes that correspond directly with MachineInstr opcodes. These
37| /// are used to represent selected instructions. See the isMachineOpcode()
38| /// and getMachineOpcode() member functions of SDNode.
39| ///
40| enum NodeType {
41| 
42|   /// DELETED_NODE - This is an illegal value that is used to catch
43|   /// errors.  This opcode is not a legal opcode for any node.
44|   DELETED_NODE,
45| 
46|   /// EntryToken - This is the marker used to indicate the start of a region.
47|   EntryToken,
48| 
49|   /// TokenFactor - This node takes multiple tokens as input and produces a
50|   /// single token result. This is used to represent the fact that the operand
51|   /// operators are independent of each other.
52|   TokenFactor,
53| 
54|   /// AssertSext, AssertZext - These nodes record if a register contains a
55|   /// value that has already been zero or sign extended from a narrower type.
56|   /// These nodes take two operands.  The first is the node that has already
57|   /// been extended, and the second is a value type node indicating the width
58|   /// of the extension.
59|   /// NOTE: In case of the source value (or any vector element value) is
60|   /// poisoned the assertion will not be true for that value.
61|   AssertSext,
62|   AssertZext,
63| 
64|   /// AssertAlign - These nodes record if a register contains a value that
65|   /// has a known alignment and the trailing bits are known to be zero.
